views.name: All tours grouped by transportation type

rows.field_36853: Rotterdam is a vibrant city that’s sure to surprise and entice you in equal measure. Full of must-see attractions and world-famous architecture, there’s also a whole other side to the Dutch city that’s worth exploring. Here’s your guide to the best of secret spots in Rotterdam, the futuristic city of the Netherlands!

Rotterdam pub crawl is an amazing way to connect with other travellers and locals in a safe and loose surrounding. You will spend the whole night with people from all over the world, share cultures and experiences while enjoying a drink in the beautiful nightlife of Rotterdam.
Rotterdam is a crowded and busy harbour city. However, if you want to get away from all the hustle and bustle, there are also surprising pieces of nature to be found in and close to the city.

Learn about the artists from past and present during this bus tour. Perfect for new and seasoned visitors to NYC, hear little-known facts about Edgar Allan Poe, Bob Dylan, Jimi Hendrix, and countless others, that you wouldn’t hear if exploring independently.

Discover New York City's storied past with a gangsters and ghosts walking tour. Meet your guide for a history tour with a twist and learn about the city's crimes, gangsters, back room deals, and haunted buildings. Stroll between several downtown neighborhoods including Little Italy, Chinatown, and the West Village while listening to spooky stories and mob tales.

Spend a day exploring the Mount Fuji area on this private, fully customizable tour. Your English-speaking driver will pick you up from your central Tokyo hotel and take you to spots such as the Sengen Shrine Complex, Kawaguchiko Lake, and Oshino Hakkai.

Delve into Paris’s rich and layered past with this historical tour. Visit key landmarks such as Notre-Dame Cathedral, the Pantheon, and Les Invalides, learning about the city’s role in shaping French and world history. Discover hidden gems and stories that reveal Paris’s fascinating heritage from the medieval period through to the modern day.

Immerse yourself in Paris's artistic grandeur on this fine arts tour. Explore the legendary Louvre Museum, the Impressionist masterpieces of Musée d'Orsay, and the architectural wonder of Palais Garnier. Perfect for art lovers, this tour offers a deep dive into the city’s artistic heritage from the Renaissance to modern times.

Experience the culinary delights of Paris with a food-focused tour inspired by the famous movie Ratatouille. Visit markets, charming bistros, and local eateries where you’ll taste traditional French cuisine. Discover the origins of beloved Parisian dishes while exploring the picturesque streets that inspired this iconic film.

Relax and unwind on a tranquil tour through Paris’s most beautiful gardens. Visit the lush Luxembourg Gardens, the elegant Tuileries Garden, and the lesser-known Parc Monceau. This tour offers a peaceful retreat from the urban hustle, showcasing the city's green spaces, sculptures, and botanical beauty.

Heule, a charming district of Kortrijk, offers a delightful blend of history and heritage waiting to be discovered. While often overlooked, this quaint area is home to hidden gems and captivating monuments that tell the story of its rich past. From centuries-old landmarks to lesser-known sites, there's much more to Heule than meets the eye. Here’s your guide to the best of secret monuments in Heule, a historical treasure in the heart of West Flanders!

views.name: All highlights grouped by city and type
Add new highlight
views.title: Add a new tour stop
views.description: Use this form to add a new tour stop. You can link a stop to multiple tours.

field_options.description: A short description about the tour stop
A fun fact about the stop that the guide can mention
Select the type of tour stop
An image to use in the website and brochures

rows.field_36880:
Do you remember that time you were so drunk you fell over? Well, probably not.

In any case, Café de Riddert is so small this wouldn’t even be possible! This brown café, just around the corner from Centraal Station, offers special beers, whiskeys, and live music.

The beer casks are stored underneath the floor, so it happens quite often that you have to step away from the bar to make room for the floor to open up — it’s magical! For this bar, we can say three make a crowd.
rows.field_36887: The bar "De witte aap" was once voted the best bar in the world

rows.field_36880:
Rotterdam has three famous parks to the north side of the river: Vroesenpark, Kralingse Bos, and Het Park (a.k.a. the Euromast park).

But did you know that next to Het Park, behind a little stream, some trees, and a fence, you can find a little park called Schoonoord? Walk past its gates and find yourself in a big garden dating back to the year 1706!

This place used to be someone’s backyard, but now it’s open and free to visit for everyone. The park has a beautiful pond, a botanical garden, birds, and trees over 250 years old! You can even adopt one of the trees, and no — you can’t carve your name in it.

This is the perfect place to take your date and have a glass of wine. Just make sure it’s a day-drinking date because the park closes at 4:30 PM.
rows.field_36887: There’s a tree more than 130 years old at Westersingel

rows.field_36880:
Close to the Feyenoord football stadium, an exit leads to a tiny bridge. This bridge will take you to Brienenoord Island. An island with forest, open waters, and Scottish Highlanders.

The animals are tame, so you can walk next to them. Just don’t feed these furry friends! Have you seen that Gremlins movie? Well, then you’ll know what happens if you feed them.

Halfway through the island, you’ll find little cottages with gardens full of veggies and plants. Walking underneath the Brienenoord bridge is quite impressive and a huge contrast with the rest of the island, full of nature. Because of the bridge and the noise of the cars, it may not be the perfect place for some quiet nature, but you do get some nice skyline views.
rows.field_36887: Rotterdam is home to 73 bridges

rows.field_36879: Restaurant Gare Du Nord train wagon
rows.field_36880:
This is one of those hidden places, and you only find it if you are vegan or if you have watched way too many Thomas the Tank Engine episodes. We found this place when we were looking for a good pub-crawl route.

You’ll find Gare Du Nord just behind the old Hofplein train station. Even though this place might sound fancy, it’s not expensive. Just make sure you make a reservation if you are going for dinner. If you feel like a rebel and want to eat a sandwich on a train, this is for you.
rows.field_36887: Rotterdam is home to 905 restaurants

rows.field_36880:
After you’ve had your lovely hummus quinoa bean falafel potato herb burger, walk over to the old Hofplein train station to enjoy the view with a beer.

This station is built on top of the old train tracks, where you will find a little garden growing herbs, fruits, veggies, and other plants. In summer, you might even stumble upon an event.

If you always wanted to walk over train tracks without being hit, this is your chance! Rotterdam plans to convert all the old Hofplein train tracks into a 1.2 km long park, just like they did in New York. This station is connected to the famous yellow pedestrian bridge “de Luchtsingel”, which also connects to the Biergarten.
rows.field_36887: The Hofplein (square) was a populair clubbing area

rows.field_36880:
Biergarten might be the least hidden spot on this list, and if you have lived here for more than 10 seconds, you will probably already know this place. Normally, this is the first location we take our international friends, as it is close to Centraal Station and in summer, a great place to grab a drink and have some food.

Clubs like Annabel surrounding the garden are closed during the day, but in the evening, everyone is mingling.
rows.field_36887: There are 37 museums in Rotterdam

rows.field_36880:
You don’t have to go to Zeeland or the north to find islands — there is one in Rotterdam! Noordereiland is floating between the north and south of Rotterdam and is connected by De Willemsbrug and Koninginnebrug.

While the island is officially part of the city’s south side and neighbourhood Feijenoord, people keep debating whether it is the “real” south. Noordereiland, therefore, remains stuck in the middle.

The island played a very important role at the beginning of World War II. When the German army caught the Dutch by surprise at the old Willemsbrug on May 10, 1940, the Dutch marines and army fought straight at the south side of the bridge for four days.

Even though the Dutch army was weak, surprised, and not modernised yet, the Dutch were able to keep the German forces from taking the bridges. Of course, this changed after the city bombardment on May 14, 1940.

Next to the island’s rich history, it has great views and locations to take pictures. On the north side, you will have a great skyline view in front of the historical houses. On the west side, you’ll find a unique angle of the Maastoren and Erasmusbrug.

Did you know they have their own flag? The Rotterdam flag is horizontal green white stripes with a heart added in the middle. So, bring your camera or a book and put on “Stuck in the middle” by Jimmy Eat World or “Stuck in the middle with you” by Stealers Wheelers (pun intended).

The Maastunnel is the oldest “sunken” tunnel in the Netherlands, opened in 1942 during World War II. The tunnel was built on the mainland and sunken into the water after.

Next to the car tunnel, the city built a cyclist and pedestrian tunnel. If you ever feel like walking 1.2 kilometres to the other side of the city for no reason, this tunnel could be your friend!
rows.field_36887: The previous flagship of the Holland Amerika cruise line is still in Rotterdam

rows.field_36880: Take the elevator to the 7th floor of De Rotterdam to enjoy even greater free skyline views. The fancy Nhow hotel bar has crazy expensive food, but it’s a great place for a few drinks. Also, a good area to party in the night.
rows.field_36887: Napoleon once stayed in Rotterdam and stayed in Schielandshuis.

rows.field_36880:
Would we be right if we said that you probably hadn’t discovered this cosy garden yet? The town hall at Coolsingel, built between 1914 and 1920, has two entrances on both sides of the building to enter the garden.

It’s a public space and free to enter. The garden is pretty small, but hey, it is not about size. It is about the kind of sandwich you bring. Amazingly, this kind of silence is hidden in the city’s centre.
rows.field_36887: The coat of arms of Rotterdam is green wit green, has a crown and four lions

rows.field_36880:
Did you know that all small harbours and docks in the Rotterdam centre are named after what they used to import and export? Veerhaven (feather), Bierhaven (beer), and Wijnhaven (wine). Guess what they brew? Right, beer! British red lightship floating in Wijnhaven was turned into a bar and restaurant with English food.

You can sit outside on the deck in summer, but if it is colder, just cosy up inside in the living room and order a home-brewed ale, lager, stout or IPA. The bar rents out little floating hot tubs, so you can float around the canals in your swimsuit whilst drinking an IPA.

The bar is close to the Maritime Museum and Stad Zonder Hart WWII memorial statue. Get to this bar by leaving the metro at Beurs.
rows.field_36887: You can travel the city by water taxi.

rows.field_36880:
I’ll take you to the west part of town for this location. The M4H area is full of old renovated buildings that store artists, musicians, and creative and innovative concepts.

The neighbourhood used to be notorious for men roaming the streets, seeking a lady to satisfy them for five minutes. Mark our words, this area will be the new Katendrecht within 10 years. Meaning, there’s not too much yet, but it will bloom and boom soon!

One of the bigger projects is the Dakpark on top of a big shopping centre. A nice place to relax if you happen to be in the neighbourhood.

Bring your children because in summer they turn on the water fountains! It has a rooftop restaurant, so you can always find restrooms and grab some beers. Just take the metro to Marconiplein, or park in the underground garage at Vierhavenstraat 79.
rows.field_36887: There are 38 cube houses in Rotterdam

rows.field_36880: When Italian immigrants moved to this Manhattan neighborhood in the late 1800s, they brought their customs, food and language. That heritage remains evident today—Little Italy’s streets are lined with restaurants serving Italian staples on red-and-white checkered tablecloths.
rows.field_36887: The neighborhood served as a haven for Italian culture and cuisine, while also distinctly partitioned along regional loyalties. Sicilians could primarily be found on Elizabeth Street, Northern Italians on Bleecker Street, and the Genovese on Baxter Street.

rows.field_36880: With an estimated population of 90,000 to 100,000 people, Chinatown is home to the highest concentration of Chinese people in the Western Hemisphere. Manhattan's Chinatown is also one of the oldest Chinese ethnic enclaves.
rows.field_36887: Before 1965, Chinatown's population was overwhelmingly male

rows.field_36880: West Village attracts many people who enjoy designer boutiques and trendy restaurants. Rows of Federal-style homes alternate with public plazas along the neighborhood's picturesque and often cobbled streets. Well-known nightlife spots include the Village Vanguard jazz club and the Stonewall Inn bar, which was the scene of riots in 1969 that led to the creation of the gay rights movement. In this historic cultural district there are also piano bars, variety restaurants and theaters.
rows.field_36887: Due to its location just west of Indian Village, the neighborhood was named West Village in the mid-20th century.

rows.field_36880: Well-known for its arch, honouring George Washington, the man for whom the park is named, and its fountain, the arch's elder by 43 years and a popular meeting spot, Washington Square Park also houses several other monuments and facilities.
rows.field_36887: he Washington Square Arch is modeled after the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, France.

rows.field_36880: Building, Exxon Building and McGraw-Hill Building, as well as Radio City Music Hall. The Steinway Hall of New York was moved to 1133 Sixth Avenue in 2016. Sixth Avenue is the site of the annual Village Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village and the Dominican Day Parade in Midtown
rows.field_36887: The Sixth Avenue extension was opened to traffic in 1930, and the subway line was completed two years later.

rows.field_36880: Greenwich Village and its winding streets were already here when the rest of Manhattan’s streets were laid out as a grid in the early 19th century. See those crooked streets and more during a guided walking tour that covers more than 200 years of history. Check out the beautiful, historic brownstone residential buildings and the area’s bars and restaurants.
rows.field_36887: Greenwich Village was once declared an independent republic.

rows.field_36880: Strawberry Fields is a 10,000 m² section of New York's Central Park, dedicated to English musician John Lennon. The area is named after the Lennon-McCartney song Strawberry Fields Forever, which in turn is named after the children's home in Liverpool near where Lennon grew up.
rows.field_36887: Strawberry Field was a Salvation Army home in Liverpool where John Lennon used to go

rows.field_36880: Shibuya was historically the site of a castle in which the Shibuya family resided from the 11th century through the Edo period. Following the opening of the Yamanote Line in 1885, Shibuya began to emerge as a railway terminal for southwestern Tokyo and eventually as a major commercial and entertainment center.

Rising to 12,388 feet (3,776 metres), Mount Fuji is the tallest mountain in Japan and is known for its graceful conical form. It is the country's sacred symbol, and temples and shrines are located around and on the volcano.
rows.field_36887: Mount Fuji is an active volcano

rows.field_36880: Kitaguchi Hongu Fuji Sengen Shrine (Fujiyoshida Sengen Shrine) is the traditional starting point of the Yoshidaguchi Climbing Trail. Pilgrims would come here to pray before beginning their ascent up the north side of Mt. Fuji.
rows.field_36887: The shrine contains 26 individual structures making it one of the largest in all of Japan

rows.field_36880: Lake Kawaguchiko is the most easily accessible of the Fuji Five Lakes with train and direct bus connections to Tokyo. A hot spring resort town with various tourist attractions and views of Mount Fuji is located around the lake's eastern end, while the northern and western shores are mostly undeveloped.
rows.field_36887: It is one of the Five Fuji Lakes and it is the second largest of them all.

rows.field_36880: Oshino Hakkai (literally Eight Seas in Oshino) are the eight springs found in Oshino, Yamanashi, Japan. The aquifer water from Mount Fuji comes out to the ground to form these springs. They are a Natural monument of Japan, part of the Mount Fuji World Heritage Site, and one of Yamanashi Prefecture's important tourist attractions.
rows.field_36887: In 1934, it was selected as one of the 60 Selected Waters of Japan by the Environment Agency.

rows.field_36880: The iconic iron structure built for the 1889 World's Fair, offering panoramic views of Paris.
rows.field_36887: The Eiffel Tower is painted every 7 years.

rows.field_36880: A famous Gothic cathedral known for its stunning architecture and history.
rows.field_36887: The Notre-Dame bell weighs 13 tons.

rows.field_36880: The world's largest art museum and a historic monument in Paris.
rows.field_36887: The Louvre was originally a fortress.

rows.field_36880: A monument honoring those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars.
rows.field_36887: The Arc de Triomphe is 50 meters tall.

rows.field_36880: A basilica located at the summit of Montmartre, the highest point in the city.
rows.field_36887: The Sacre-Coeur took 39 years to complete.

rows.field_36880: An art museum housed in a former railway station, featuring works from the 19th century.
rows.field_36887: The Musée d'Orsay was once a train station.

rows.field_36880: The largest square in Paris, known for its historical significance and the Luxor Obelisk.
rows.field_36887: The obelisk is over 3,000 years old.

rows.field_36880: A royal château located just outside of Paris, known for its opulent architecture and gardens.
rows.field_36887: The Hall of Mirrors contains 357 mirrors.

rows.field_36880: A historic district known for its artistic history and the stunning views from the top of the hill.
rows.field_36887: Picasso lived in Montmartre.

rows.field_36880: One of the most famous avenues in the world, known for its theaters, cafes, and luxury shops.
rows.field_36887: The Champs-Élysées is 1.9 kilometers long.

rows.field_36880: A beautiful public park featuring a palace, fountains, and statues.
rows.field_36887: The park is owned by the French Senate.

rows.field_36880: A mausoleum containing the remains of distinguished French citizens.
rows.field_36887: Foucault's Pendulum was first demonstrated here.

rows.field_36880: A famous cabaret known for its iconic red windmill and French cancan dance shows.
rows.field_36887: The Moulin Rouge opened in 1889.

rows.field_36880: A square known for its fashionable and luxurious stores.
rows.field_36887: The Vendôme Column was made from melted cannons.

rows.field_36880: A deck arch bridge connecting the Champs-Élysées quarter with the Invalides and Eiffel Tower.
rows.field_36887: The bridge is named after the Russian Tsar Alexander III.

rows.field_36880: A Gothic-style royal chapel built to house relics.
rows.field_36887: Sainte-Chapelle has 15 stunning stained glass windows.

rows.field_36880: A public garden located between the Louvre and Place de la Concorde.
rows.field_36887: The garden was originally created by Queen Catherine de Medici.

rows.field_36880: A complex of buildings containing museums and monuments, including Napoleon’s tomb.
rows.field_36887: Napoleon is buried under a dome of gold.

rows.field_36880: A 1,979-seat opera house, one of the most famous in the world.
rows.field_36887: The Palais Garnier is the setting for The Phantom of the Opera.

rows.field_36880: A museum dedicated to the works of French sculptor Auguste Rodin, set in his former home.
rows.field_36887: The Thinker is one of the museum's most famous sculptures.

rows.field_36880: This traditional windmill is a well-preserved relic of Heule's agricultural past, offering a glimpse into the region’s milling heritage.
rows.field_36887: Preetjes Molen is one of the few remaining working windmills in the area and still grinds grain in the traditional way during special events.

rows.field_36880: Nestled along the Lys River, the Watermolen is a picturesque watermill that played a vital role in local industry centuries ago.
rows.field_36887: The Watermolen dates back to the Middle Ages and once served as the lifeblood of the local economy, grinding grain for the entire community.

rows.field_36880: This historic building, now a popular local shop, combines modern retail with Heule's architectural charm.
rows.field_36887: Lucardi is located in a building that once served as a meeting place for local traders, maintaining its commercial roots even today.

rows.field_36880: Warande is a beautiful green park where locals come to relax and enjoy nature, boasting scenic paths and a peaceful atmosphere.
rows.field_36887: The park was once part of the estate of a noble family, and remnants of their grand garden design can still be seen today.

rows.field_36880: This stunning castle is one of Heule's most iconic landmarks, with its origins tracing back to medieval times.
rows.field_36887: Kasteel van Heule has undergone multiple transformations, including a stint as a luxurious country house for aristocrats, making it a true historical gem.
